thread.title: White House might hire ex-Navy SEAL in favor of Muslim registry
thread.title_full: White House might hire ex-Navy SEAL in favor of Muslim registry

author: CHRIS SOMMERFELDT
title: White House might hire ex-Navy SEAL in favor of Muslim registry
text:
Carl Higbie with Donald Trump, who's Higbie's book, "Enemies, Foreigh and Domestic — a SEAL's Story." (Carl Higbie via Facebook) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  26 PM 
The White House might be looking to hire a former Trump campaign surrogate who once cited Japanese internment camps as "precedent" for a Muslim registry, the Daily News has learned. 
Carl Higbie, an ex-Navy SEAL and the spokesman for the defunct Great America PAC, told The News Friday evening that he has been in contact with White House officials over a possible position within the Trump administration. 
"I've offered my services to the administration in whatever capacity they could use me," Higbie said, declining to comment further. 
Higbie, who was among President Trump's first official surrogates on the campaign trail, gained notoriety after citing the human rights-abusing Japanese internment camps kept in the U.S. during World War II as "precedent" for implementing a national registry system for Muslims. Higbie was among President Trump's first official surrogates on the campaign trail. (Carl Higbie via Twitter) 
"We've done it based on race, we've done it based on religion, we've done it based on region. We've done it with Iran back — back a while ago. We did it during World War II with Japanese," Higbie told former Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly in November after she pointed out that a registry based on religion could trigger widespread abuse. 
President-elect Trump had at the time floated the idea that American Muslims should be registered. 
More than 110,000 Americans of Japanese descent were forcibly relocated and incarcerated in internment camps after the Japanese Empire attacked the Pearl Harbor naval base on Dec. 7, 1941. The camps marked a dark moment in American history and the Carter administration concluded in 1980 that they were caused by racism, not sound political policy. More than 110,000 Americans of Japanese descent were forcibly relocated and incarcerated in internment camps during World War II. (ASSOCIATED PRESS) 
Matthew Dallek: Japanese internment vs. a Muslim registry 
Two senior administration officials told the Washingtonian that Higbie has been interviewing for the White House press secretary position, which is currently held by Sean Spicer. 
A Trump administration spokeswoman vehemently denied that notion, telling The News in an email that the report "is completely false." A report suggested Higbie might be interviewing for the White House press secretary post, which is currently held by Sean Spicer. (Carolyn Kaster/AP) 
"I've even talked to Carl personally and he even said it was not true," the spokeswoman said. 
Numerous reports have come out in recent weeks suggesting that President Trump has been unhappy with Spicer's performance as press secretary, and even regrets picking him. 
The White House has blasted the reports as inaccurate. Join the Conversation:
